Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2011 01:01AM momoftwo526 wrote: Zeana: So sorry for your loss.  I lost my mother to this awful disease in 1965 when I was just 15 years old and still feel a void in my life for missing her.  It is obvious that you had a wonderful relationship with her.  She sleeps with the angels now and has no more pain!  God bless. Phyllis
Posts.Title: My Mother Is Sleeping Now BrokenHeart marieibrahim

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2011 10:17AM momoftwo526 wrote: My father had 5 sisters.  1 sister had ovarian cancer and died at the age of 35.  2 sisters had breast cancer 1 had brain cancer.  1 of the ones with bc died at 45.  The eldest sister became afraid to be with the other because she irrationally thought she could catch the cancer.  FEAR.  Fear is such a disabler. All of the sister died from their cancers.  The one without cancer died in her 80's of heart failure.  She may just be afraid to reach out.  Call her, write her ask her why!  Good luck.
Posts.Title: People who disappear after diagnosis rosasmommy rosasmommy

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 03:08PM momoftwo526 wrote: Your Dr. is right.  Calcifications may be just that  --- benign calcifications.  I had 3 calcification (in a cluster too!) removed in 2003 that were benign.  Also, they put in markers any time they remove the whole suspicious lump, which is typical for calcifications or small tumors.  I had markers in both breasts.  This makes it easier for them to find the area again if they biopsy shows any abnormalities.  They also want that for future reference for mammograms in future years as well.  I know how hard it is to wait for the results.  Praying for good news for you and like Marie said, keep yourself as busy as you can! Phyllis
Posts.Title: Biopsy Today... chconnol momoftwo526

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 12:32AM momoftwo526 wrote: Michgreg: Hugs to you!  And it is ok to cry, it is normal to cry.  let it out!  So sorry you have to go through this. Phyllis
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2011 01:49PM momoftwo526 wrote: Just thought I would put my 2 cents in here.  I have BC coming from both sides -- Mother died of BC, sister is a 20 year survivor.  She has a different father than me, so that is definitely on my mom's side.  Father's side:  He had 5 sister's.  2 had breast cancer, 1 ovarian and 1 brain.  Also on my father's side, at least 5 of the daughter's of my aunts with some type of cancer have had breast cancer. I do not test positvie for the BRCA1 or 2 gene.  NEVER has any Dr. tell me that the cancer history on my father's side is insignificant!  They just say I have a double whammy.  AND they had also said that the fact I am not BRCA1/2 negative does not mean that it is not genetic.  It means that it is likely we have a gene that has not yet been identified. I have been getting mammograms since I was 30 yrs old because of family history -- every year.  My breasts are fibrocystic and dense.  I have almost always had to go back for additional views, US and/or MRI.  I have had multiple biopsies and cyst aspirations.  This year, the mammogram showed an abnormality.  Got called back in for US.  Referred to BS.  He did a core needle biopsy.  That came back negative, but he wanted to remove the lump anyway since the cells were abnormal and given my family history, etc, he figured we should take it out and be done with it.  Guess, what?! It was invasive cancer!  Thank God for my BS!  It is Stage 1, medium growing.  Who knows what would have happened 6 months down the road if he hadn't decided to take it out now instead of waiting.  You should get that lump out or at the very least biopsied.  Now, that is my 2 cents! Phyllis
Posts.Title: Paternal breast cancer history Trabby SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 07:42PM momoftwo526 wrote: I had a lumpectomy with the wire insertion.  They numb the breast before insertion.  It is very thin and I hardly felt it at all.  I joked with the surgeon as to what channels he thought I would get!  I originally had a core needle biopsy, which had come up negative, but there were still some abnormal cells, so, because I have a deep family history of bc, they decided to remove the lump and biopsy it.  I was told that there was a less than 5% chance of it being cancer.  Much to my surprise and dismay, it turned out to be cancer.  Stage1, grade2, ILC, LCIS, ER+, PR+, HER2-.  Margins are not all clear.  Still have to make a decision about next steps. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Wire insertion before Lumpectomy? Chrys23 AMP614

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2011 04:12PM momoftwo526 wrote: I have surgery today to drain a large seroma and they will put in another drain too.  I still have 1 drain in the other side which is still outputting between 110 to 140 cc per day.  I am 6 weeks out from surgery. I hate the drains, but my Dr. says that while there is a risk of infection from leaving them in, there is greater risk from leaving all that fluid in your body.  Phyllis

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2011 01:21PM momoftwo526 wrote: I remember my mother rolling over in bed and cracking her rib.  Later, we found out her BC had metastisized to her bones and liver.  She died of BC in 1968, so she did not have the options or treatments available today.
